docs.lead_paragraph: This year is the 50th anniversary of the first successful human organ transplant. Over the last half-century, the improved understanding of how to prevent the body's immune system from rejecting foreign tissue has turned what began as an experiment into a routine procedure. Today, bone and bowel, heart and hand are replaceable. Now we are confronting the imminent possibility that human faces will be transplanted. This month in The American Journal of Bioethics, a team of transplant surgeons at the University of Louisville announced their intention to pursue the transplantation of faces. Last year, a task force at the Royal College of Surgeons of England cautioned against them.

headline.main: A Stranger in the Mirror: Should Doctors Transplant Faces?

docs.abstract: University of Louisville transplant team, led by Dr John Barker, has announced intention to explore transplantation of human face, despite calls from medical community that further research in face transplantation needs to be conducted before actual surgeries take place; concerns over anti-rejection medications and their potential harmful side effects described; technology is available, but ethical concerns about elective face surgery have deterred its widespread application; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The technology for human facial transplants exists, but ethicists are worried about using it.

byline.original: By ERIC F. TRUMP and KAREN MASCHKE

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors trying to assess a patient's chances of dying from heart disease routinely consider risk factors like cholesterol levels, smoking and family history. A new study says they may also want to take into account whether the patient has graduated from high school.
docs.abstract: Dr Kevin Fiscella of University of Rochester medical school and Dr Peter Franks of University of California, Davis, medical school lead study that suggests increased risk of heart disease for individuals without high school diploma; study, published in Annals of Family Medicine, finds uneducated people are two and half times as likely to die of heart disease as educated individuals; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study says doctors trying to assess a patient's chances of dying from heart disease may want to take into account whether the patient has graduated from high school.

docs.lead_paragraph: The death of Christopher Reeve illustrated something that those who live with paralysis know all too well: the challenges go far beyond the inability to walk. ''Walking is the least of it,'' said Donna Messinger, who is 43 and has been paralyzed since an automobile accident in her senior year of college.

headline.main: With Paralysis, Challenge Goes Beyond Walking

docs.abstract: Individuals living with paralysis experience many physical challenges besides not being able to walk; Infectious Diseases Society of America reports that infection is number one cause of death for paralyzed individuals; Dr Kristjan Ragnarsson, Mount Sinai Medical Center rehabilitation medicine chairman, holds lung infections are very common when patient requires assistance to breathe; Christopher Reeve, who recently died of cardiac arrest, had been treated for severe infection brought on by pressure wounds or bed sores; championed efforts to improve quality of life for people with spinal cord injuries; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The death of Christopher Reeve illustrated something that those who live with paralysis know all too well: for quadriplegics, infection is Public Enemy No. 1.

docs.lead_paragraph: When his clock-radio goes off at 7 a.m., David Epstein's latest wake-up strategy roars into high gear: he stumbles out of bed, walks across the room and pushes the snooze button. Then he climbs between the sheets. A few minutes later, his travel clock rings. He presses snooze and rolls over for more sleep -- until the alarm on his BlackBerry goes off. Sitting up, he punches keys to reset it for 10 more minutes, then it's back to the pillow.

headline.main: Snooze Alarm Takes Its Toll on a Nation

docs.abstract: Sleep researchers agree that short periods of sleep are not as effective as sustained sleep; hold that dozing and waking, from repeated use of snooze alarm, causes shifts in brain-wave patterns; Dr Timothy Roehrs, Henry Ford Hospital Sleep Disorders and Research Center research director, leads study published in journal Sleep that measures effects of limited sleep on mental and physical abilities; decision-making, memory, creativity, attitude and overall health are found to be negatively impacted by sleep deprivation; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Is a bumpy arousal from sleep a way to recoup much-needed sleep? Or is it a recipe for exhaustion?

docs.lead_paragraph: People who exercise only at the end of the week have lower mortality rates than people who are sedentary, a new study says. The report, which says it is the first to look at weekend-only athletes, appears in the current American Journal of Epidemiology. The findings do not mean that people should disregard the advice of health experts to exercise at least several times during the week, said the lead author, Dr. I-Min Lee, an epidemiologist at the Harvard School of Public Health.

headline.main: Score One for the Weekend Athlete

docs.abstract: Dr I-Min Lee, Harvard University School of Public Health epidemiologist, leads research that suggests people who workout only on weekends are better off health-wise than those who do not exercise at all; study is published in American Journal of Epidemiology; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who exercise only at the end of the week have lower mortality rates than people who are sedentary, a new study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- The flu vaccine can give you a case of influenza. THE FACTS -- With the start of the flu season just weeks away, the rush to get vaccinated has begun. This year the nation faces a severe shortage of vaccine, leading health officials to urge Americans to reserve flu shots for people at highest risk. These include very young children, adults 65 and older, people with chronic medical disorders and health care workers. The shortage was caused when the British government temporarily suspended the license of the Chiron Corporation to make the flu vaccine.
docs.abstract: Getting vaccinated for flu does not cause influenza; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some Americans are reluctant to get the flu vaccine in part because of unfounded fears that the virus used to manufacture it can cause influenza.

docs.lead_paragraph: If supermarkets had beauty contests for their products and I were the judge, the fresh produce section would win every time: thousands of colorful foods neatly and attractively displayed, certainly more enticing than raw meats and poultry or the vast array of canned, frozen and packaged foods. So why is it so difficult to get Americans to eat more fruits and vegetables, for the sake of their weight as well as their overall health? The five-a-day campaign of the National Institutes of Health, the American Cancer Society and the American Heart Association has raised consumer consciousness of fresh produce, but increases in consumption still lag sadly behind. The major growth vegetable remains potatoes -- deep-fried, of course.

headline.main: Vegetables? Sure. We'll Take Some Fries.

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses importance of eating fruits and vegetables and reasons why consumption may not be as high as it should be; lack of time to prepare food and eating out often are two main reasons cited for trend; changes at home, school and food markets are suggested to help Americans get more fresh produce and maintain healthier life styles; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many shoppers treat the produce section more as an art exhibit than as the source of delicious, nutritious, health-promoting and, in some cases, even lifesaving foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wild birds are the ultimate source of all avian flus -- but that, scientists argue, does not mean that they are important in spreading the current virus or should be wiped out to stop it. Scientists searching for the roots of the A(H5N1) virus that is threatening to turn into a human pandemic consider live bird markets, traveling poultry workers and the movement of domestic poultry and fighting cocks more likely vectors for spreading the disease from country to country and from farm to farm.

headline.main: Experts Call Wild Birds Victims, Not Vectors

docs.abstract: Wild birds are being blamed for spread of avian flu throughout Asia by some local health officials and others; Dr Juan Lubroth, United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's infectious disease group senior officer, asserts there is no evidence that wild birds are culprits; holds they are victims of illness; evidence points to human impact on spread of avian influenza through live bird markets, bird fighting and improper cleaning of bird feces-covered truck tires and shoes; vaccination and regulation to try to control avian flu discussed; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Wild birds are the ultimate source of all avian flus - but that, scientists argue, does not mean that they are important in spreading the current virus or should be wiped out to stop it.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS
